Tuple class header.

License

types

namespace types

Tuple

template<typename... T> struct Tuple: Tuple_Base<0, T...>

Tuples represent compile-time lists.  They can hold multiple values of different types.  You can’t append to them, they are initialized statically.

Example

types::Tuple<int, String, float> t = make_tuple(5, "foo", 4.3f);
printf(
    "%i %s %f\n",
    types::get<0>(t),
    types::get<1>(t),
    types::get<2>(t)
);

You can construct tuples, you can assign them and you can compare them.  You can also set their members using references, get their members and unpack them as function arguments (see unpack).  You can as well get their size.

Variables

Tuple_Size

template<typename T> struct Tuple_Size

Using this, you can retrieve tuple size.  Usage

types::Tuple<int, float, int, const char*> t;
size_t size = types::Tuple_Size<t>::value;

Functions

get

template<size_t i, typename... T> inline typename Add_Ref< typename Tuple_Element<i, Tuple<T...> >::type >::type get(
   Tuple<T...> &v
)

Gets a tuple element.  Usage

types::Tuple<int, float> t;
int value = types::get<0>(t);

This returns a mutable reference.

get

template<size_t i, typename... T> inline typename Add_Const_Ref< typename Tuple_Element<i, Tuple<T...> >::type >::type get(
   const Tuple<T...> &v
)

Same as above, but it returns a const reference.

!=

template<typename... T, typename... U> inline bool operator!=(
   const Tuple<T...> &a,
   const Tuple<U...> &b

template<typename... T, typename... U> inline bool operator<=(const Tuple<T...>& a, const Tuple<U...>& b)

>=

template<typename... T, typename... U> inline bool operator>=(
   const Tuple<T...> &a,
   const Tuple<U...> &b

make_tuple

template<typename... T> inline Tuple<T...> make_tuple(T... args)

Constructs a tuple from given arguments.

tie

template<typename... T> inline Tuple<T&...> tie(T&... args)

Creates a tuple of lvalue references to its arguments.

unpack

template<typename T, typename... U, typename... V> T unpack(
   T (*fun)(U...),
   const Tuple<V...> &t
)

Unpacks a tuple as function arguments.  Example

void fun(int a, float b, const char *c)
{
    printf("%i %f %s\n", a, b, c);
}
auto t = types::make_tuple(5, 6.78f, "foo");
types::unpack(&fun, t);
